reference.shortdesc: The cause element describes a potential source of the problem that is described in the troubleshooting topic. Changed to "The cause element describes a potential source of the problem.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: The cause element is a component of a cause and remedy pair. The cause might be omitted if it is implicit or if the remedy is not associated with a cause.

section.p: This information should be brief. If it is not possible to make the information brief, this might be a sign that a full troubleshooting topic is needed.

example.draft-comment:
Note that the content in the <cause> example contains a suggested solution. Premature. If, based on what is in <cause>, the customer reseats the board and something gets fried â€“ my company is on the hook to replace/service the board for free. Support teams want customers to have maximum context before performing a corrective action. Separating cause analysis from remedies is a best practice. This example appears in multiple sections.
Kris Eberlein, 12 February 2023
@Stan, I think you are raising several points here, so I'll list them in an ordered list (in order to make talking about the points easier):
Quality of examples. Here in the spec, we need to straddle the line between "realistic examples" and examples that are simple enough for the spec reader to grasp. Obviously, this is especially difficult for troubleshooting topics, which can be complex both in structure and in content.
This example appeared in the DITA 1.3 spec, however, it did use the responsibleParty element to indicate that reseating the board is a task that should be performed by a maintenance technician. Would you be more comfortable if this example added that element back? Or do you want to create an alternate example?
Separating causes from remedies. Is your concern with the 2nd sentence in the cause element? We could remove it. I do want to comment that the very nature of the troubleSolution element suggests that there is a relationship between a cause and a remedy.
Modeling best practices for troubleshooting topic content. While we don't want to have any egregious content in spec examples, we really cannot expect these topics to model authoring best practices. That is always going to be something that an individual company needs to decide for their content authors.
